name: Product Market Fit
description: Product-market fit (PMF) across these episodes is treated as a moving target: finding a repeatable value proposition for a specific customer in a specific context, then proving it with retention, pull, and a scalable distribution motion. The theme addresses how to diagnose whether growth problems are really acquisition issues vs. weak/shifted PMF, how to narrow to a beachhead, and how to evolve positioning, category, and strategy as markets and competitors change—because scaling before PMF (or after PMF has drifted) is one of the fastest paths to wasted spend and team burnout.
subtopics: Diagnosing PMF vs. growth/channel problems (what to fix first, and how to tell)
Finding demand through customer narratives: Jobs-to-be-Done, struggling moments, and the real competitive set
Beachhead selection and sequencing expansion (crossing the chasm, bowling pins, adjacency strategy)
Packaging and positioning for PMF: category choice (create vs. compete), buyer language, and “sugar-coated broccoli”
Operationalizing PMF evidence: qualitative signal loops + quantitative metrics, and when to invest in growth hiring/functions
PMF drift and resilience: adapting to market shifts, incumbent pressure, and repeated near-death moments
common_frameworks: Jobs-to-be-Done (demand-side research, struggling moments, hire/fire narratives)
Crossing the Chasm: beachhead focus + “bowling pin” adjacency expansion
Signal loops: continuous customer feedback cycles (1:1s, observation, rapid iteration)
PMF vs. growth diagnosis (separating distribution/channel constraints from product/value constraints)
Category design / category strategy (create vs. compete; positioning via buyer language and budget reality)
Power / defensibility thinking (early strategy and “power progression” alongside PMF work)
